newsitem.title: USA: KCBT wheat slips to lowest level since July 1994.
newsitem.headline: KCBT wheat slips to lowest level since July 1994.

text.p: KCBT hard red winter wheat futures slipped to the lowest level in almost three years, weakened by bearish spring wheat acreage data and spillover selling from tumbling CBOT soybeans.
Floor sources said continued reports of higher-than-expected yields in Kansas and Oklahoma wheat were also weighing on the market.

USDA put spring wheat acreage at a higher-than-expected 19.2 million acres. A Reuter survey of analysts had produced an average projection of 18.1 million acres. Soybean area was put at 70.9 million versus an average analysts' estimate of 68.4 million.
July dipped to a contract low of $3.31-1/2 a bushel, the lowest level for the nearby month since July 1994. At 1111 CDT July stood 4-1/4 cents lower at $3.35.
Floor sources noted active bear spreading, partly sparked by continued reports of good harvest progress.
Some inter-market spread trade was also noted and centered on selling MGE spring wheat and buying in both Kansas City and Chicago wheat markets.
